description:
iSeahorse is an online ‘citizen science’ tool for seahorse conservation. 

Developed by Project Seahorse, a marine conservation organization based at the University of British Columbia and Zoological Society of London, iSeahorse harnesses the power of divers, photographers, scientists, and other seahorse enthusiasts around the world to improve our understanding of these elusive and threatened animals.

Anyone who encounters a seahorse in the wild can upload their photos and sighting information to www.iSeahorse.org. Project Seahorse scientists will then use this vital information to map data-deficient seahorse populations, determine their threat levels, and develop effective conservation actions. 
 
We know that seahorses face significant threats to their survival as a species. Unfortunately, we don’t know the true extent to which they are threatened. iSeahorse will allow more data to be gathered to study seahorses in the wild, which is often difficult due to their ability to blend, chameleon-like, into the seagrass beds, coral reefs, and other coastal marine habitats they call home. 
 
By sharing results, we can all work to regulate the seahorse trade, develop marine protected areas, and engage more people in ocean conservation.
 
The beta version of iSeahorse launched in October 2012. A public launch is planned for the fall of 2013, with iPhone and Android apps to follow later in the year.
terms:
By using iSeahorse, you agree to the terms of this Privacy and Use Agreement. iSeahorse is provided by Project Seahorse, a research unit of The University of British Columbia, Canada, which together are hereafter referred to as 'Project Seahorse', 'we', or 'us'.

Submitting Information

Seahorse observations

By submitting your seahorse observations (“Observations”) to iSeahorse, you are making them available to Project Seahorse for research, education, conservation, and management purposes.

Your Observations remain yours and you are free to make this information available to others. However, by submitting your Observations to iSeahorse, you hereby grant Project Seahorse a worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty-free, sublicenseable and transferable license to use, reproduce, distribute, display, and summarize your Observations for research, education, conservation, and management purposes in any media format and through any media channels. This license is perpetual and irrevocable.

Observations you submit to iSeahorse must not contain third party copyrighted material, or material that is subject to other third party proprietary rights, unless you have permission from the rightful owner of the material or you are otherwise legally entitled to post the material and to grant Project Seahorse all of the license rights granted herein.

Due to the commercial value of seahorses, we will only make some of your Observation details public. More sensitive information, such as the exact location of the seahorses, are not available through the iSeahorse interface – and are only accessible by the user that submitted the Observation and by Project Seahorse.

Your Observation data may be made available upon request, and at the discretion of Project Seahorse, to anyone for the purposes of research, education, conservation and management (this does not include personal information – see above, or Images – see below). Your Observation data may also be shared with other applications developed by the global biodiversity information community, such as the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (gbif.org) or FishBase (fishbase.org). iSeahorse data are stored in a secure facility at The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada, and archived daily.

Photos and Videos

By uploading photographic and videographic images (“Images”) to iSeahorse, you are making them available to Project Seahorse for research, education, conservation, and management purposes.

Your Images remain yours and you are free to make them available to others. However, you grant to Project Seahorse a worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty-free, sublicenseable and transferable license to use, reproduce, distribute, and display these Images for research, education, conservation and management purposes in any media format and through any media channels. This license is perpetual and irrevocable.

By uploading Images to iSeahorse, you are representing that you own the Images or have permission from the rightful owner of the Images to upload them or you are otherwise legally entitled to upload the Images and to grant Project Seahorse all of the license rights granted herein.

General

You may not submit fake or knowingly erroneous Observations to iSeahorse. You may not use iSeahorse for any unlawful purpose, or to infringe the rights of others on the site. You may not use iSeahorse for advertising or for promotion. You may not post comments or information that is offensive or objectionable. We do not guarantee or make any representations about the accuracy of comments posted on iSeahorse, and comments posted by users on iSeahorse do not reflect the opinions of Project Seahorse or its host institutions.
We reserve the right to remove any material posted on iSeahorse that we consider unsuitable for any reason, at any time. We also reserve the right to exclude anyone from using iSeahorse if they have posted material contrary to this Privacy and Use Agreement. If you see something on iSeahorse that is not acceptable, please report it immediately.

Using Information

You are welcome to use Observation data, figures and maps from iSeahorse only for your own, personal, non-commercial use, with credit given to iSeahorse/Project Seahorse as appropriate.

The Images uploaded by users to the site are owned by those users. You may use the Images to assist in identification of the seahorses and for other iSeahorse related purposes. You may not use any Images uploaded to iSeahorse for any non-iSeahorse related purpose unless the owner of the Images grants you that right.

iSeahorse observation data may made available upon request, and at the discretion of Project Seahorse, to anyone for the purposes of research and conservation. This does not include any user’s personal information or images.

Changes to this Privacy and Use Agreement

We may occasionally update or amend the iSeahorse Privacy and Use Agreement. If we make changes, we will post them here and where they are substantial, send an email to all registered users notifying of the change.
title: iSeahorse
project_observation_rule_terms: must be on list|must have observation field 'Region' filled out|must have observation field 'Type of activity' filled out|must have observation field 'Seahorse habitat' filled out|must have observation field 'Type of activity' filled out|must be georeferenced|must be identified

observation_field.allowed_values: |West Indian Ocean and Red Sea|East Atlantic and Mediterannean|Eastern Pacific|Indo-Pacific|West Atlantic|Australia and New Zealand
observation_field.name: Region

observation_field.description: What were you doing when you saw this seahorse? Underwater (SCUBA, snorkelling, swimming); Fishing (seahorses you may have captured or observed while fishing - it does not matter what you were fishing for); From land (coastal walk, beachcombing, etc.)
observation_field.name: Type of activity

observation_field.description: This is the amount of time you spent engaged in the activity - and does not include the time spent travelling to or from the dive or fishing site, for example.
observation_field.name: Activity duration (minutes)

observation_field.description: How far did you travel while engaged in the activity?
observation_field.name: Activity distance (meters)
If diving or fishing, maximum depth (meters)
If diving or fishing, average depth (meters)

observation_field.description: Depth at which seahorse(s) was found (for all activities)
observation_field.name: Seahorse(s) depth (meters)
If fishing, what species were you targeting?
If selected 'Other' for 'gear type used', please describe

observation_field.description: How confident are you in identifying this species?
observation_field.name: Identification confidence

observation_field.description: How many seahorses did you see at this time?
observation_field.name: No. of seahorse(s) observed

observation_field.description: What the seahorse was holding onto
observation_field.name: Holdfast
Have you seen seahorses here before?
Have you seen these same seahorses here before?
If yes above, have you reported your previous sightings to iSeahorse?
Was the seahorse inside a marine protected area?

observation_field.description: How many people were with you when you were engaged in the activity?
observation_field.name: No. of people in party

observation_field.description: Are other people from your party also submitting observations?
observation_field.name: Others submitting observation(s)
